title: What element has 6 protons, 6 neutrons, and 5 electrons? - Quora

response.answer_text: An element with 6 protons and 6 neutrons is for sure carbon. But when 5 electrons come into picture, that becomes dingy. The number of protons stated as six means that we are definitely talking about carbon as their is no other element to have the same atomic number, a property unique to every element. Five electrons indicates one less electron than should have been in a neutral atom so you'll now have a positively charged cation-C+. P. S. C+ does not much of exist.

When trying to identify the element think PROTONS. The number of protons determines the identity of the element. This element, since it has 6 protons, can be identified as carbon. If you want to further describe the element, you can say: The element is a carbon ion with a charge of +The specific isotope is carbon-12, the most abundant isotope of carbon.

If it has six protons, it's Carbon. If it has six neutrons (for a total of 12 protons and neutrons together), it's the carbon-12 isotope. And if it has five electrons, it's slightly ionized (it's supposed to have one electron per proton); but because it's too easy to gain or lose electrons, there's no special name for this.
Carbon. Specifically, carbon-12 with a +1 charge:  The identity of an element is determined by the number of protons alone. All atoms with six protons are carbon atoms, period.

Carbon 12. Six protons makes it carbon. The twelve nucleons means that it’s Carbon 12. The fact that it only has five electrons means that it has been singly ionised but there is no way to determine what ionised it.

It is a + ion of carbon-12 6 protons indicates that it is carbon. 5 electrons tells us that it is a + ion. 6 neutrons, plus the 6 protons, informs us that it is the C-12 isotope —Yuhan Zhang (Proud A-level Chemistry student)
An element is defined by the number of protons, so the answer is carbon. The rest of the information is irrelevant.
